newsitem.title: USA: PC-operating systems shipments up 9.6 pct - report.
newsitem.headline: PC-operating systems shipments up 9.6 pct - report.

text.p: Worldwide shipments of personal computer operating systems rose 9.6 percent last year to 74.8 million units, market research company International Data Corp estimated in a report Monday.

The increase from 68.3 million operating systems shipped in 1996 was below IDC's original estimate of a 15.6 percent growth rate, largely reflecting a sluggishness in PC sales, said Dan Kusnetzky, an IDC research director.
Operating system shipments closely track PC sales, although some personal computers have more than one operating system and some operating system software is sold separately.
Microsoft Corp's Windows 95 was easily the market leader in 1996, accounting for 62.9 percent of all operating systems shipped, up from 28.6 percent the year before, Kusnetzky said.
Microsoft's Windows 3.x and DOS operating system accounted for 17.4 percent of systems shipped, down from 49.1 percent in 1995, according to IDC estimates.
Microsoft Windows NT Workstation rose to 3 percent of the market from 0.8 percent the year before.
International Business Machines Corp's OS/2 system faded to 3.3 percent of the market from 6.2 percent in 1995, while various versions of DOS alone fell to 3.3 percent from 5.1 percent.
Apple Computer Inc's Macintosh operating system fell to 6.6 percent of the overall market from 6.8 percent, Kusnetzky said.
The IDC report, which does not count operating system upgrades, is based largely on figures reported by the software makers supplemented by interviews with computer manufacturers and others.
